Gansao, you've been very reasonable in your approach to this topic, asking compelling questions and explaining your position. And yes I have thought about this issue very hard for a long time. I used to be a christian, youth ministries leader, in the financial board, and on the audio/video team of my church less than 3 years ago. And yes I would say that I have a well above average knowledge of the scriptures. However the reasons for realizing that God doesn't exist are very compelling and if we really go into them we would probably seriously derail this topic. 
 
 As to whether God can be justified for all the attrocious acts, unrealistic morals and incredulous claims comes down to one single question: what is God doing NOW? Where is the single tangible trace that suggests that anything in the bible is based on things that actually occured?
 
 What I use as my litmus test are the promises of the bible. There are countless promises in the bible, that is, conditional statements that clearly state what action God will take if certain things are done. The problem is that the vast majority of these promises are so vague that nobody has a clue as to whether God actually held up his end of the deal. For example, the bible says that the effectual fervent prayer of a righteous man availeth much. How do you tell when your prayer is effectual and fervent, even if you were a righteous man to begin with? And what does prayer that avails mean? Is it answered immediately? Who knows? Another famous one that comes to mind is from malachi 3:10 "Bring ye all the tithes into the storehouse, that there may be meat in mine house, and prove me now herewith, saith the LORD of hosts, if I will not open you the windows of heaven, and pour you out a blessing, that there shall not be room enough to receive it." How can this possibly happen? Do a poll and find out if anybody in history has ever been blessed so much that they didn't have room to contain it. 
 
 So my test is narrowed down to just a few promises that have relatively measurable results. One is the promise of jesus that greater works than what he did his disciples (and christians) will also do. The other is children obey your parents, that it may be well with you and that your days may be long in the eath. Unfortunately, both these tests fail. No christians are performing miracles, and obedient children still die young. 
 
 As cynical and skeptical as I am sometimes, I know fully well that I would have no problem believing God, justifying his injustices with zeal, and even gladly oppressing heathens like you, if there was any indication that God and his power were real today. Lucky for you that's a futile search.

There are countless promises in the bible, that is, conditional statements that clearly state what action God will take if certain things are done. The problem is that the vast majority of these promises are so vague that nobody has a clue as to whether God actually held up his end of the deal. For example, the bible says that the effectual fervent prayer of a righteous man availeth much. How do you tell when your prayer is effectual and fervent, even if you were a righteous man to begin with? And what does prayer that avails mean? Is it answered immediately? Who knows? Another famous one that comes to mind is from malachi 3:10 "Bring ye all the tithes into the storehouse, that there may be meat in mine house, and prove me now herewith, saith the LORD of hosts, if I will not open you the windows of heaven, and pour you out a blessing, that there shall not be room enough to receive it." How can this possibly happen? Do a poll and find out if anybody in history has ever been blessed so much that they didn't have room to contain it. 
 
 So my test is narrowed down to just a few promises that have relatively measurable results. One is the promise of jesus that greater works than what he did his disciples (and christians) will also do. The other is children obey your parents, that it may be well with you and that your days may be long in the eath. Unfortunately, both these tests fail. No christians are performing miracles, and obedient children still die young. 
 
 As cynical and skeptical as I am sometimes, I know fully well that I would have no problem believing God, justifying his injustices with zeal, and even gladly oppressing heathens like you, if there was any indication that God and his power were real today. Lucky for you that's a futile search.

For me, the bible and the question of the existence of god are two separate questions. I believed in god much longer than I believed in the bible. My eyes were opened to the bible when I sat down and actually read the whole thing cover to cover for the first time. I was 12 years old. Almost immediately I was struck by how transparent and blatantly archaic the text was. It was obvious to me that the words came, not from god, but from ancient farmers and nomads. Some of it was superstitious drivel, some was an apparent attempt to control the masses and empower the status quo, and some of it was simple written history. I think more than anything the story of Job proved to me that the bible wasn't accurate. All of man's petty emotions are projected on god making it obvious that god (at least the biblical one) was indeed created by man in his own image.
 
 Once I figured out that the bible wasn't what it holds itself out to be, I began to look at god itself. Through the next couple of years, I began to really look at the world around me and I began to learn about physics. The world around me was (is) filled with hunger, rape, pedophilia, murder, and pain. What kind of god would create a world and then abandon it to the wolves? As to physics, I learned that the basic rules of the universe are balanced perfectly on a razors edge and allow for things to work in exactly the way we find them to work. There is no god in the equations.
 
 Now the question seemed to be...is there a god that created an imperfect world and then left it mired in s$Rt or is there no god at all. At first glance the effective outcome is the same. Either way we get the world we have now with all the pain and suffering. However, the questions are still important because if there was a 'father' who effectively ignored our plight I'd be even angrier. Without a god, I can effectively put the blame, where it belongs, on the individual wrong doers. Furthermore, I can work toward a better world and not accept the way things are as just 'that's how god made it.'
